                                                                                                                                                    OPTICS.
                                                                                                                                                science        of optics explains
                                                                                                                          THE
                                                                                                                                                                                     the
                                                                                                                                           nature       of   vision,   by investigating
                                                                                                                          the causes           of       the various phenomena' that
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:16 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          arise from the refraction and reflection'                       of
                                                                                                                          light.            It is   divided into Dioptrics, Catop
                                                                                                                          trics, and Chromatics*.                       The first treats
                                                                                                                          of refraction             ;    the    second,   of reflection    ;
                                                                                                                          and the last,             of    colours.

                                                                                                                                       Optical appearances.

                                                                                                                          f~\P               senses

                                                                                                                          reserved for posterity.         It frequently   hap

                                                                                                                          To set fire to a combujiible body, by tie            re'
                                                                                                                               jleSlion of two concave mirrors.
                                                                                                                                       rays    of a luminous body placed
                                                                                                                          THE
                                                                                                                            in the          focus of a concave mirror be
                                                                                                                          ing reflected in parallel lines,         if   a second
                                                                                                                          mirror be placed diametrically opposite the
                                                                                                                          first, it will,    by collecting those rays in
                                                                                                                          its focus, set fire to a combustible body.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             Place two concave mirrors,             A    and B
                                                                                                                          (PI.   XII. Fig.   2.) at about twelve or fifteen
                                                                                                                                                            4        . feet

                                                                                                                                   RECkEATIONS.                               131
                                                                                                                          feet distance From each other, and let the
                                                                                                                          axis   of each of    them be in the fame line.
                                                                                                                          In   the fociis C,       of them, place a
                                                                                                                                                   of   one
                                                                                                                          live coal and in the focus D of the other,
                                                                                                                          some gunpowder.     With a pair of double
                                                                                                                          bellows,       which make a continual blast,
                                                                                                                          keep constantly blowing the coal, and not
                                                                                                                          withstanding the distance               between them

                                                                                                                                       CHROMATICS.

                                                                                                                                          DEFINITIONS.
                                                                                                                               1 r   Those rays of light that are all equal
                                                                                                                          ly refrangible,           are called simple or homo-
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          geneal rays.

                                                                                                                          grees       of refrangibility,         are    called com
                                                                                                                          pound, or heterogeneal*.

                                                                                                                            4. Those of heterogeneal light, secon
                                                                                                                          dary or compound colours.
                                                                                                                               5.     A   spectrum is a coloured           image       of
                                                                                                                          the sun, produced by the refraction                     of    a
                                                                                                                          ray of light let into a dark chamber.

                                                                                                                                             APHORISMS.
                                                                                                                              1.      All    the colours       in nature proceed
                                                                                                                          from the rays of light.
                                                                                                                             2. There            are   seven     primary colours,
                                                                                                                          which are red, orange, yellow, green, blue,
                                                                                                                          indigo, and violet.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                             3.       Every ray of light may           be separated
                                                                                                                          into the seven primary colours.
                                                                                                                             4. The rays of light in passing through
                                                                                                                          the fame medium have different degrees
                                                                                                                          of refrangibility.
                                                                                                                              5. The difference in the colours of light
                                                                                                                          arises from its different refrangibility, that
                                                                                                                          which is the least refrangible producing
                                                                                                                          red,     and that which is the most refrangi
                                                                                                                          ble, violet*.

                                                                                                                                    The artificial rainbow.
                                                                                                                          /"OPPOSITE          a window into which the
                                                                                                                                sun shines direct,       suspend   a glass

                                                                                                                                                                         of

                                                                                                                          of   about forty degreJ§*^jfyou will see,               by

                                                                                                                          purple colour in the glass, and by draw

                                                                                                                          matic colours,           blue, green,     yellow, and

                                                                                                                          raised to about           fifty degrees, when they
                                                                                                                          will again       be seen,    but in an inverted or
                                                                                                                          der, the red appearing first, and the blue
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          or violet last     :    and when the globe comes
                                                                                                                          up to little more           than fifty-four degrees
                                                                                                                          they     will totally     vanish.
                                                                                                                               These appearances serve to explain the
                                                                                                                          phenomena          of    natural rainbows,    of which
                                                                                                                          there are frequently two ; the one being
                                                                                                                          about eight degrees above the other,                  and
                                                                                                                          the order        of    their colours is inverted, as
                                                                                                                               * That is if you suppose an arch of      a   circle to
                                                                                                                          be drawn from the horizon to the
                                                                                                                                                              zenith} and di
                                                                                                                          vided into ninety equal parts or degrees, the globe
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          must be raised to the height        of forty of those de
                                                                                                                          grees.
                                                                                                                                                                                  in

                                                                                                                          i56        RATIONAL
                                                                                                                          in this experiment, red being the upper
                                                                                                                          most: colour in the lower bow, and violet
                                                                                                                          in the other.
                                                                                                                             The rainbow      is not in the clouds, but
                                                                                                                          in the falling rain, and always opposite
                                                                                                                          the sun. The different order of the co
                                                                                                                          lours in the bows arises from their diffe
                                                                                                                          rent reflections ; those   of   the under bow
                                                                                                                          being caused by two refractions        and one
                                                                                                                          reflection, and those of the upper, by two
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          refractions and two reflections, and there
                                                                                                                          fore the colours of this are less bright than
                                                                                                                          the other, their strength being diminished
                                                                                                                          by every reflection.
                                                                                                                             Now, it      has been proved    by repeated
                                                                                                                          experiments,     that forty degrees forms the
                                                                                                                          greatest angle by which      the most refran
                                                                                                                          gible rays can, after one reflection, be re
                                                                                                                          fracted   to the eye; and that something
                                                                                                                          more than forty-two degrees         forms the
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          greatest angl?, under      which the   least re
                                                                                                                          frangible rays can come to the eye after
                                                                                                                                                                      one

                                                                                                                                   RECREATIONS.                             157
                                                                                                                          one reflection.    Therefore all the colours
                                                                                                                          of the lower bow    must lie in the space          of
                                                                                                                          less   than two degrees.     In like   manner it
                                                                                                                          has been proved,    that fifty degrees make
                                                                                                                          the least   angle under which the least re
                                                                                                                          frangible rays can be visib'e to the eye
                                                                                                                          after two reflections;     and that about fifty-
                                                                                                                          four degrees will be the least angle under
                                                                                                                          which the most refrangible rays can come
                                                                                                                          to the eye after two reflections.        There
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          fore all the colours of the upper bow must
                                                                                                                          be in less than four degrees.
                                                                                                                             It follows from what is here said,             that
                                                                                                                          all rainbows are of a circular form               and
                                                                                                                          equal magnitude, and as they are always
                                                                                                                          opposite the sun, the parts we see      of   them

                                                                                                                          the horizon   when his altitude is forty
                                                                                                                                         :
                                                                                                                          degrees, only the upper rainbow can be

Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          sun's height, during the winterhalfyear, is
                                                                                                                          rever equal to forty degrees, theiemay
                                                                                                                          then be always two bows visible.

                                                                                                                                             *Ihe Æolipiles.
                                                                                                                                    æolipile is a small globe    of   brass or
                                                                                                                          ANother metal, into which aflender neck
                                                                                                                          or pipe is inserted. This ball, when made
                                                                                                                          red hot, is cast into a vessel of water,
                                                                                                                          which will rush into its cavity, then
                                                                                                                          almost void of air. The ball being then
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-11-02 19:17 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015018448988
                                                                                                                          set   on the fire, the water, by the rarefac
                                                                                                                          tion of the internal air, will be forced out
                                                                                                                          in    steam, by fits,   with great violence, and
                                                                                                                          with    a strange noise.
                                                                                                                                If to the necks   of two or    more   of   these
                                                                                                                          æolipiles there be fitted those calls that are
                                                                                                                          used by fowlers and hunters, and the æoli
                                                                                                                          piles be then placed privately on the fire ;
                                                                                                                          as thesteamrushesforththey will make such
                                                                                                                          a horrible noise, that a person who is            ig
                                                                                                                          norant of the contrivance cannot fail being
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          greatly astonishing,

                                                                                                                          202             RATIONAL
                                                                                                                               Great care should be taken that the neck
                                                                                                                          of   the æolipile be not stopped when it is
                                                                                                                          placed on the fire, for in that case it would
                                                                                                                          burst, and might do no small mischief.

                                                                                                                                         The communicative busts.
                                                                                                                          T        ET     there be two heads      of plaster of
                                                                                                                               '   Paris, placed on pedestals, on the op
                                                                                                                          posite sides     of   a room.     There must    be a

                                                                                                                          tin tube of an inch diameter, that must
                                                                                                                          pass from the ear        of one   head, through the
                                                                                                                          pedestal, under the floor, and go up to
                                                                                                                          the mouth of the other.            Observe, that the
                                                                                                                          end      of   the tube which is next the ear      of
                                                                                                                          the      one head,       should    be   considerably
                                                                                                                          larger than that end which comes to the
                                                                                                                          mouth of the other.             Let the whole   be so
                                                                                                                          disposed       that there may not be the        least
                                                                                                                          suspicion      of a   communication.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                Now, when        a person speaks, quite low,
                                                                                                                          into the ear of one bust, the sound is re-
                                                                                                                                                                       verber

                                                                                                                                     RECREATIONS.                          203
                                                                                                                          verberated through the length          of the   tube,
                                                                                                                          and will be distinctly heard by any one
                                                                                                                          who shall place his ear to the mouth of the
                                                                                                                          other.     It   is not   necessary    that the tube
                                                                                                                          should come to the lips of the bust.               If
                                                                                                                          there be two tubes, one going to ihe ear,
                                                                                                                          and the other to the mouth of each head,
